content.body: By the way, for everyone here who told me about screen (Hixie? jgraham?): you rock.
(or rather encouraged me to use it, it's not like I hadn't heard about it)
screen is indeed awesome
if screen could fill my xterm scrollback buffers when i connect to it, rather than handle scrolling itself, i might use it more
screen is why I have such high IRC uptime
i run my shells under emacs, so emacs takes care of it

i want an irc proxy so i can stay connected, but use an irc client locally. and i want the proxy to feed my client scrollback content too when i connect to it. (up to a reasonable amount, say a day or two. but to include excerpts outside this time period if my nick is mentioned.)
why do you want a local client?
i am happy with x-chat
although i am quite happy reading my mail in mutt over ssh, a text-based irc client doesn't do anything for me for some reason
i don't really know how to tell the difference... irc is text
heycam: welcome back
Text-based IRC clients annoy me too.
I don't have a very good reason for this, though.
I tried irssi but didn't feel it was worth it to learn how to use it.
Oh, also I think it only let me use one window for all channels, which is unacceptable.
I have a whole monitor with six channels tiled across it.
also not clear to me what a text-based IRC client is
means curses-based?
One that runs in a terminal.
Instead of a GUI app.
ah
runs in a terminal, not GUI
like irssi?
ok
I am a long time GUI IRC client user
ever since X-Chat back in the day
now it's 100% Colloquy
even though Colloquy doesn't quite do everything I would like
it is usable and pretty to look at
I recently switched from XChat to Colloquy and been very happy to have made the switch
also, WebKit
yeah
plus active developers
I feel compelled to demonstrate my patriotism
and responsive developers
on #colloquy
I really dislike XChat.
NoOneButMe++
akempgen++
Colloquy sounds great, too bad I use Linux.
and of course xenon++++++++++
I'm pretty sure that's a syntax error.
Well, you have an even number of plus signs, so conceivably not, but it's certainly not recommended coding style.
X-Chat feels crufty compared to Colloquy now, though to be fair, lately I have only run it on Windows
dunno if it feels better in its native habitat
because of public wifi in several places in Australia blocking port 6667 when I was traveling there, I recently set up screen+irssi and been pretty happy with that too
yoo hoo
that's me
I find irssi with the nm.pl and wlstat.pl plugins to be fairly usable
nm does proper aligning an coloring of nicks
wlstat.pl gives you a human-readable channel list at the bottom of the screen
and irssi handles unicode with no problems too
anyway, the trend at http://arewefastyet.com/ is very cool
I hate Colloquy. I have not been able to figure out how to collect alerted messages so I can read them even if they've escaped from scrollback
roc: yeah, that's annoying
MikeSmith: there's also: http://arewefirstyet.com/
micheil: thanks
micheil: what's this measuring?
where the search terms for JavaScript rank on google
it also has crazy bugs where it sometimes stops redrawing
as currently if you look for help on JS, the decent documentation is no where to be seen
and sometimes there are visual artifacts
roc: ping NoOneButMe or akempgen on #colloquy
I think there's also a bug tracker for Colloquy but can't remember where
and there's no support for user-configured hyperlinking
yet
I still use it
obviously something is wrong with me
anyway I'm switching to Windows soon, so it doesn't matter
roc: http://colloquy.info?bugs or http://colloquy.info/project/report/1
wow, 536 bugs
536 *active* bugs
Colloquy needs some more developers…
http://arewefastyet.com/ makes me wonder whether that point on the Sunspider graph around 370ms or whatever is going to be where all the implementations will end up plateauing for a while
there is a lot of room for improvement in Colloquy
MikeSmith: check out how many active bugs mozilla or webkit have ;-)
Hixie: well, yeah
would be more fair to compare how many bugs Chatzilla has, maybe
number of open bugs is a function of the size of the QA base, not the engineering base

about I meant maybe everybody will plateau (or whatever better word) there due to all having basically reached the same limits as far as what performance can be squeezed using the current techniques (that have come around in the last 2 years or whatever)
bug in / out rate are more interesting metrics than open bug level IMO
Number of open bugs is a function of the size of the bug-reporter base.
Hixie: I think in the case of Colloquy, it's the same base
bugzilla.mozilla.org also has bugs for lots of non-Firefox things. Like every time a Mozilla employee requests hardware, that's a bug
we also have bugs assigned to the legal department
I don't know who maintains http://arewefastyet.com/ but it might be worthwhile to add Opera to it
Carakan
MikeSmith, #3 on http://arewefastyet.com/faq.html
MikeSmith: dvander⊙mc However, they can't add Carakan easily because no standalone JS shell is available
jgraham: ↑ gsnedders
MikeSmith: I think we'll probably plateau on Sunspider because we don't think it's a great benchmark at this point, so once we've beaten everybody else the incentive to keep going is low
AryehGregor: thanks
roc: I see
I know JS benchmarks are kind of touchy subject anyway
hey guys, is it possible to check if an image is a part of another image? guessing i'd have to use canvas.
from js?
there's no direct api for it
"part of"?
you could as you say implement it manually using canvas to get the image data
roc: so maybe I shouldn't have brought it up here… but anyway, it's great to see the progress that chart shows has been made over the last couple months
Philip`, like one image is a piece of another
touchy? we do touchy here :-)
for example a picture of a human, the sub-image may just be the head, and i want to check if the whole body contains the head image inside
I'm not sure what is touchy though
Like you have a 10x10 image and a 20x20 image and want to see if any 10x10 region of the larger image is precisely identical to the smaller image?
MikeSmith, thanks!
roc: I suspect there was probably a measurable difference just do the fact of heycam joining the mozilla team :) that's the kind of voodoo he seems to have
Philip`, yes
(and yeah i meant curses based)
he's stuck in Auckland so hasn't had much chance to influence the rest of Mozilla yet :-)
heh
lol
heycam: you moved already?
I really want to visit Auckland
you dudes please find me a business reason to travel to Auckland for a visit
yeah just arrived a few weeks ago
come on over :)
anyone got an animated GIF with frame numbers? a testcase animated gif?
brb lunch

Peter`: when I first read "The Chromium Team chose to enable their implementation of the FileSystem API by default. ", it seemed like it implied there was some other WebKit-based implementation of the FileSystem API
maybe "The Chromium Team recently implemented the FileSystem API, and has now chosen to enable it by default in Chrome." or something would be better
(or maybe it's just me)
"There is a downside too, as the advocated API is asynchronous, it has a steep learning curve."
in general, do asynchronous APIs have a really steeper learning curve than synchronous ones?
I mean, once you get past the initial step of learning how to program that way at all?
hmm, I guess they do
[Craig]: Sounds like getImageData and a string search is the best you can do, then
or at least, they are necessarily always more complicated a bit at least

Mozilla people (roc, sicking): how long should I wait before poking people about checkin-needed not being checked in?  And who do I poke?  It's been five days.  https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=586763
AryehGregor: dao is a good person to poke
or gavin perhaps (not sure if he still does that)
dao landed something for me monday morning
in theory i could do it, but in practice the tree scares me
I can check it in tomorrow
gavin, thanks.
AryehGregor: the best thing to do is ask around in #developers on irc.mozilla.org
oh, gavin already answered you
AryehGregor: i might give it a try tonight if i don't get home too late
Okay, thanks.
wonders why @html5douche tweeted non-doucheily
ha, this is way more amusing than i thought it would be
damn you heycam for ruining my concentration ;)
heycam: I think it's because he forgot what account he was tweeting from…
MikeSmith, likely!
cool to see this:
http://dougt.org/wordpress/2010/10/desktop-notifications-in-fennec/
annevk should be happy
heycam: did you hear that annevk is a WG chair now?
of the Web Notification WG
MikeSmith, I did!
all grown up
heh
Hixie: FYI: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=605373
scoping object strikes again :-(
yeah, unfortunately IE's behaviour is basically a non-starter on that one
(they just drop the <object> from the DOM entirely)
we'll always have regressions
or pages that don't parse ideally
since there are pages depending on different contradictory behaviours
at some point we just have to draw a line and accept it
(dunno which side of the line this one is on)

anyone have an opinion on whether it's better to use multiple <aside>s for different bits of a sidebar, such as a blogroll and an archive list, or to use a single <aside> with multiple child <section>s?
shepazu: both are fine
shepazu: really it depends whether stylistically it would be fine for one part to be elsewhere or whether the whole thing should always stick together
Hixie: thanks, I thought that might be the answer... now I have to decide how related the sections are... doing some tweaking of http://www.w3.org/Graphics/SVG/
might be good to have separate asides, so the different sections could be reordered, put on different sides of the page, etc...  anyway, good to know that both are reasonable
MikeSmith: it's mainly the idea of asynchronous programming which is hard for people to understand
Hixie: I'm pretty sure we has at least a couple of sites break due to the <object> thing. I meant to look up the sites but didn't
given the wacked out things IE does with <object> i would expect it to be one of less successful areas
Right, but that doesn't mean that we need to gratuitously break sites if it is avoidable
Since no one else but IE used the IE behaviour and these breakages are regressions
jgraham: at this point, reading the code of the old WebKit tree builder in order to figure out what exactly it did would be nice
no progress on https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=46936
aaaargh. interaction with legacy stuff strikes again: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=604660

amongst some open video software developers we are developing a proposal for HTTP adaptive streaming - mostly focused on Ogg and WebM with some specifications for extending HTML5 APIs - I wonder if it would be appropriate to chuck this into the WHATWG wiki in preparation for discussions on the mailing list?
jgraham: oh i'm not saying we shouldn't fix it if there's a good fix that does more good than harm
jgraham: just that i'm not surprised to see that kind of problem come up
nessy, go ahead
annevk: cool, ta
WHATWG wiki is open for most everything, and definitely everything that is related to web standards
ArrayBuffer exposes endianness?
oh well
I wish the script running section of the spec had reminded me that XSLT-inserted scripts need to behave like parser-inserted scripts
Oh man, I hadn't even considered the possibility of xslt inserted scripts
Can you make xslt work with text/html content during parsing? I can't think of an easy way but there could be something I missed
jgraham: do you mean applying XSLT to text/html during parsing?
Yes
jgraham: not with anything equivalent to <?xml-stylesheet, no
jgraham: I have no idea what would happen if you passed a document that's still being parsed to the XSLT JS API
That was more what I was wondering about
I believe XSLT-created scripts in the JS API case should be prevented from executing like innerHTML-created scripts
...or maybe not
happy happy time ahead with scripts inserted via XSLTProcessor and createContextualFragment
stuff I've learned today: an XSLT transform fails to compile in Gecko if it doesn't have the version="1.0" attribute
why does Chrome throw a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR when moving a node from an XSLT result doc to an HTML page?
Isn't that a case where DOM Core literalism would make you use adoptNode?
hsivonen, WebKit has not yet removed throwing WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR for certain scenarios
jgraham: yeah
annevk: ok
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/XSLTProcessor-transformToDocument.html
Opera runs the script once it's adopted
Gecko trunk and Chrome don't run it
yay for interop
doesn't have any issues with decomplexifying XSLT support if possible
hsivonen, what hotel are you staying at for TPAC?
Hotel de congres
annevk: the one that a while ago still had the 100% .swf site
http://www.hoteldescongres.com/
seems there's less Flash now
annevk: yes and yes
number of nights... hmm
like I know
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/XSLTProcessor-transformToFragment.html
script runs in Firefox and Opera
not in WebKit
I'm staying there too now
thanks
maybe I should test DOMParser-created scripts next...
and maybe XHR-created scripts
annevk: Opera disagrees with Firefox and WebKit on http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/xhr.html
hmm. IE9 can't adopt a node from XHR into a displayed doc
boo
Gecko disagrees with WebKit and Opera: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/xhr-importNode.html
The Design of HTML5 - http://adactio.com/articles/1704
huge blog post
it's a transcription
annevk: yep of the conference Fronteers 2010
annevk: in this tweet: http://twitter.com/#!/DennisLaumen/status/27818124542
the "ik kon me geen directe pimp herinneren" part
how would you translate that/
"I can't recall a direct pimp"?
"I can't recall pimping directly"?
I do not remember direct pimping
so yeah, something like that
ok
thanks
annevk: I recall someone (you?) tweeting from fronteers that authors weren't aware that vendor-prefixed CSS properties can be discontinued at any time
annevk: do I recall correctly? are authors really thinking that the vendor-prefixed stuff is stable?
I thought they were unaware that it was "invalid"
oh
some think it is valid
I am not sure whether they think it is stable
annevk: ok. thanks
does IE9 use the new JS engine for the old document modes?
and the new Direct2D graphics layer?
Opera disagrees with Gecko, WebKit and IE9 beta 1 on http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/DOMParser.html
the weirdest thing I've learned today:
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/innerHTML-in-doc-defer-plus-cruft.html
innerHTML script runs in IE
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/innerHTML-in-doc-defer.html
innerHTML script doesn't run in IE
MSDN said defer would run
first I figured that MSDN was wrong
then I learned you need to have something in addition to the script element in the innerHTML setter argument for the script to run
hsivonen: during my recent language messings-around in twitter, I was kind of a surprised to realize there doesn't seem to be any direct article or indirect article in Finnish
is that the case?
oh
are we gonna publish today?
do I need to do anything?
yeah
change date to Oct 19
I guess I haven't merged recent changes
please do now :)
MikeSmith: do you mean like "the" or "a"/"an"?
yeah
hsivonen: ↑
I guess I have some more time
MikeSmith: there is none
(aren't those definite and indefinite, not direct and indirect?)
hsivonen: oops, yeah
I means definite/indefinite
annevk: please do get it done as soon as you can
can you give me 45min?
articles are kinda useless, so we don't have those
annevk: yeah, sure
definite vs. indefinite information is baked into the case in some cases
oops. pun unintended
hsivonen: yeah, Japanese and most asian languages don't have them either
heh
hsivonen: but Japanese speakers and other Asian non-native English learners seem to have a lot of trouble using "a" and "the" correctly in English
it's pretty hard
I don't find it conceptually that hard
but it seems like FInnish speakers don't have that problem nearly as much
I think there are some instances where it's hard
though I can't think of particulars right now
I know there are some where I had a difficult time explaining why "a" is needed instead of "the"
or vice versa
hsivonen: also, Google Translate Finnish<->English seems to be relatively poor quality
MikeSmith: yeah. I use source language to English when I use Google Translate
(and Google would use English as an intermediate language anyway)
machine translation of Japanese->English is also poor quality
the reason for it isn't because of Google Translate in particular
it's just very difficult to do decent Japanese->English machine translation
human translation quality from English to Finnish varies rather strikingly
interesting
is there a lot that needs to be inferred when doing it?
there are some books (typically non-fiction) where one can tell what the English expressions were
ah
that is, the result is Finnish, but no one would write Finnish like that from scratch
I see
I was thinking more of the other way around
from Finnish to English
in comparison, one big problem with translating Japanese to English is that the subject can be omitted from a sentences
*from sentences
that is, the sentences in the Japanese source may lack subjects
and the translator has to make a guess?
the only way to know what the subject is is to read the previous sentence or parargraph
human translator does not need to guess
ah
it's almost always unambiguous to humans
but harder to teach a machine
though not impossible of course
anyway, I was speculating that there might be some similar reasons why going from Finnish to English with machine translation might be more difficult than most
I mean, I've been surprised to find that Google Translate does a decent job with some languages that I had naively assumed it might have a lot of difficulty with
Hebrew, for example
and Arabic
and Hindi
it consistently seems to do better with all those than it does with Finnish
I think the top two things that require inference when translating from Finnish to English are using the future tense and guessing he vs. she
OK
I mean for a machine. For a human, the future vs. present information is there but not in the verbs
hsivonen: I see
hmm. So now the spec has a "Noah ark clause" in addition to the "adoption agency algorithm"
*Noah's
yeah, interesting choice of name there
there's a restaurant here in Oslo called Noah's Ark
they've got nice burgers
annevk: do they come in pairs?
unfortunately not :)
so only <video> has an audio attribute
not <audio>
hmm
MikeSmith, http://dev.w3.org/html5/html4-differences/ has been updated
fwiw, http://www.w3.org/TR/progress-events/ has been updated too
annevk: thanks
annevk: btw, you saw that Doug Turner had implemented support for the Web Notifications spec in Fennec?
I don't recall if he mentioned it on the list
I read a post last Friday I believe
yeah
and I saw you mentioning it again somewhere in the logs :)
heh
OK
I wonder if Japanese <-> Finish works well?
when I see romaji and finish's spelling, I sometimes wonder if there are not the same language. It is very strange.
karlcow: I expect the market isn't big enough for anyone to bother
hsivonen: you mean for the translation engine?
karlcow: right
(Google translates Japanese to English to Finnish when asking it to translate from Japanese to Finnish)
For the market, for sure. :) But I was more interested by the work of art :)
hsivonen: what's the current conclusion about which language family (families) Finnish belongs to?
for comparison, I think there is currently not actually a real consensus on where Japanese developed from
http://educationjapan.org/jguide/origins.html
MikeSmith: I believe the English name is Fenno-Ugric
OK
Japanese is often regarded as a possible member of the Altaic group, but the relationship is generally considered tentative or unproven.
has to go

"Altaic includes three main subfamilies (Turkic, Mongolian and Manchu-Tungus), while Uralic includes the Finn-Ugric languages (Hungarian, Finnish, Estonian, etc.) and the Samoyedic tongues (spoken in parts of Russia). "
karlcow: my understanding is that it's beens a long time since any serious researchers actually still classified Japanese in the Altaic group
but I could be wrong
MikeSmith: I'm not qualified at all. Just reading what I find. :)

"Vowel harmony is common in Altaic and Uralic languages, such as Turkish and Finnish, and later I will show how it has been used to support theories relating Japanese to these groups."  -- http://linguistics.byu.edu/classes/ling450ch/reports/japanese.htm

"Japanese is not conclusively linked to any other language or family of languages. It has remained a mystery despite all these centuries of research, and continues to prod the people who speak it to seek out their identity."
karlcow: I think it is becoming less of a mystery recently
research seems to be leaning towards this:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goguryeo_language
is reading
wants a time machine.
and poneys
ooooh and for the catastrophists, end of the world theorists or just poets ;) there is a big giant ass ring on the sun :)
so from reading http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finno-Ugric_languages I see that Hungarian and Estonian are among the languages that Finnish is related to
http://www.nasa.gov/topics/solarsystem/sunearthsystem/main/News101610-3flares.html
MikeSmith: migration of people? waves of invasion? viral language? :)
Terrible how much information has been lost
the ring is more visible on this image http://spacefellowship.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/489332main_euvfilament-20101016.jpg
karlcow: cool
Workshiva: about language history?
MikeSmith: History in general
some history can at least be reconstructed from tangible artifacts
but for extinct languages that without a written record, the info really is lost forever
I mean, there is always the possibility of archaeologists uncovering artifacts that we can recover history from about a lot of things
but not about spoken language
unrecorded spoken language
But even written history is very sparse compared to the total of reality
I have noticed lately that Chrome on OSX seems to be doing caching more aggressively than other browsers
or maybe it's just me
remote resources but also caching file:// resources and not loading them from disk after I've made changes to them, but instead keeping right on serving them from cache
seems like file:// resources should arguably never get cached to begin with
I wish there were a replacement word in English for "now"
so that I don't mistakenly type "not" when I meant to type "now"
MikeSmith: "presently"?
too long?
yeah
Philip`: e.g., "http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html5-diff-20101019/ is not ready for publication"
http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html5-diff-20101019/ is presently ready for publication
MikeSmith: you can type "ima" and have an automatic script to translate but that will severely damage your brain and you end by saying "ima" orally to English speakers :)
Why not just say "is ready for publication"
and yeah, I know I could omit "now" and it would still make sense
jgraham: I knew you would say that
Me?
:D
Philip` was far more likely
why not, is because for whatever reason, I typed "http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html5-diff-20101019/ is not ready for publication" initially
I didn't spend a whole lot of time thinking about why I wanted the "now" in there to begin with
I just typed it
mistyped it
jgraham: well, not you in particular
or a script which does "uri pub" and creates the sentence automatically :p
"you" in general
"at the moment, at present, at the present (time/moment), at this moment in time, currently, presently."

"3 you must leave now: at once, straightaway, right away, right now, this minute, this instant, immediately, instantly, directly, without further ado, promptly, without delay, as soon as possible; informal pronto, straight off, ASAP."
thanks Mr. Encyclopedia
"http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html5-diff-20101019/ is without further ado ready for publication"
hmmm
heh
coming from Apple Dictionary
"now" in Hungarian is "most"
The thesaurus section
s/without further ado/after much ado/
and you can set yourself up for a world of Shakespeare puns
is trying to guess the difference between the two jgraham gave.
reaching my English inabilities
I like "nå"
karlcow: Just that "Much ado about nothing" is the play
(so "much ado" for short)
aaaah. capice
merci
lol
Come back later! Enjoy your fall break~
Brandon
no
Chandler
I thought "capice" was Italian
I think I will just start using "ahora"
with ital
"http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html5-diff-20101019/ is ready for publication _ahora_"
I think more European speakers already know what "ahora" means, right?
wouldn't know that
really?
hmm
but agora is easier to pronunce
"now" in "nu" in Esparanto
though agora might confuse greek people
and in several other languages of course
but I don't think most native English speakers know "nu"
I wonder why Google Translate doesn't do Esparanto
seems like it used to
Hmm, I just noticed that the phrasing of the HTML5 spec around foreign content stuff makes it hard to implement in html5lib without invasive changes :(
Specifically the "except that if those rules say to reprocess the token, these steps must be finished first"
jgraham: was the text added recently?
Yeah
I see
didn't remember that being in there before
Typically the token is reprocessed by a direct call rather than by spinning the loop again with the same token
I suspect other implementations might be doing it that same way
I think it is OK for Henri as phrased
I dunno about the WebKit implementation
I wonder about the PHP parser
Ask gsnedders
tries to remember what others there are at this point
there is a DOM parser in node.js now
but it does not attempt to conform to the HTML5 spec yet
as far as I remember
I think there are actually more than one DOM implementations in node
that are in various states of development
but I think the most mature one is not HTML5-conformant
I think hober has been following the work on that one
and filed a bug
or enhancement request
that is should conform to HTML5
Writing a from scratch HTML5 parser and not following the HTML5 spec is just lame
Well naive
probably
well, people don't know
they work on a lot of stuff
they don't follow every single thing that goes on in standards land
Indeed
anyway, I think hober is on top of it
in this case
But you might have thought that if you were going to write a HTML parser you would at least check out the HTML spec
hober++
MikeSmith: Will be fine for the PHP impl, as that just spins the loop again for it ordinarily
(I know history might have taught you to regard the HTML spec as basically useless for all purposes except inciting markup purity holy wars)
gsnedders: k
MikeSmith: Not that anyone is intending on maintaining it
heh
(I refuse to implement all of the script tokenizer states again.)
about the node DOM thing, for now, I'm just glad at all to have a DOM implementation at node
I guess at some point I will end up making a reprocessToken() function or something
*in node
and tediously removing all the explicit calls
and then missing some and creating bugs
or in JS, really (which is what it comes down to)
and then finding out that there is some special case where it doesn't quite work
(I don't know how tightly bound if at all the parser might be to node)
Eventually we will be able to write a whole browser in js
heh
and you will run a browser in your browser
we certainly may be able to write a validator at least
or more specifically, an HTML5 conformance checker
Well the Mozilla people have javascript in js
I thought there was someone on the WHATWG list seriously proposing that the web platform should be extended so that it's complete enough to write a browser
yeah
and doing image decoding and stuff can't be that hard
Just need a layout engine
Surely implementing CSS 2.1 can't be that hard
It's just a load of boxes
heh
looking at Server Sent Events, and remember Pointcast http://www.nczonline.net/blog/2010/10/19/introduction-to-server-sent-events/ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Push_technology
wishes Server-Sent Events would work in Chrome, or at least he could figure out why his trivial demo isn't working in Chrome.
does HTML4 or any other spec say that ID values should be compared case-insensitively?

http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.whatwg.org%2Fspecs%2Fweb-apps%2Fcurrent-work%2Fmultipage%2Fnamed-character-references.html&charset=%28detect+automatically%29&doctype=HTML+4.01+Strict&group=1&user-agent=W3C_Validator%2F1.1
see the "ID X already defined" errors
I am wondering if the W3C validator is intentionally configured to check IDs case-insensitively for some reason
MikeSmith: ID validation in html4 inherits the sgml rules for IDs (since IDness is specified in the DTD)
OK
so next question is, did SGML have the notion of case-insensitve IDs
Hixie: Sorry for the long response :-) It is a Haptics device, my personal experiment is to make Accessibility better for disabled people (blindness)
s/long/late
hsivonen: i can't say i ever think about xslt, sorry. If you want anything added for it, file a bug, happy to add a note.
MikeSmith: yes
david_carlisle: IDs in SGML are case-insenstive, you mean?
by default yes
